review.title: Toward Automatic Understanding of the Function of Affective Language in Support Groups
review.abstract: Understanding expressions of emotions in support forums has considerable value and NLP methods are key to automating this. Many approaches understandably use subjective categories which are more fine-grained than a straightforward polarity-based spectrum. However, the definition of such categories is non-trivial and, in fact, we argue for a need to incorporate communicative elements even beyond subjectivity. To support our position, we report experiments on a sentiment-labelled corpus of posts taken from a medical support forum. We argue that not only is a more fine-grained approach to text analysis important, but simultaneously recognising the social function behind affective expressions enable a more accurate and valuable level of understanding.

metadata.title: Toward Automatic Understanding of the Function of Affective Language in Support Groups

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: There is an abundance of opinions on the Internet. The accessibility bar has been reduced to an even larger audience that can now share its voice. However, more than just opinions on external matters, people are able to share their emotions and feelings and talk openly about very personal matters. In fact, these emotions are only partially able to increase anonymity in the online presence, while all authors are able to follow the interactions face to face (Hancock et al., 2007). The forums are a platform on which users generate emotional content.

sections.heading: 2 Related Work
sections.text: In fact, it is a very selective group, which is able to see itself as being able to hold its own.

sections.heading: 3 Data
sections.text: In this section, we discuss aspects of the data that we use in detail to support the position of the paper.

sections.heading: 3.1 Data Source
sections.text: The data used here are those of Bobicev and Sokolova (2015) - an extension of the data used and described in more detail in Sokolova and Bobicev (2013). The data was gathered from contributions to discussions in a sub-forum of a medical forum on in vitro fertilization (IVF) 2, which is intended for discussion by participants of a certain age group (over 35 years). Originally, the data set (henceforth MedSenti) comprised 1321 contributions on 80 different topics.

sections.heading: 3.2 Annotation Details
sections.text: There are two approaches to commenting on subjective aspects of communication: from the perspective of the perception of a reader (Strapparava and Mihalcea, 2007) or that of the author (Balahur and Steinberger, 2009). Labeling MedSenti Sokolova and Bobicev (2013), they chose the readercentric model and asked the commentators to analyze the perception of a post as if they were other panelists. This is an important differentiation for automated classification tasks - models are built to predict how people understand the emotion an author feels as if they are being conveyed. For example, Maks and Vossen showed in review copies that the reviews reliably related to the language used than the author's original assessment. Similarly, Mehl and al showed that personality ratings perceived by a third party "via hearing" had a strong correlation to basic perceived labels.

sections.heading: 3.3 Data and Label Preprocessing
sections.text: We select document labels according to Bobicev and Sokolova (2015): If two labels match, we reduce them to a single label; if the labels do not match, the post is marked with a sixth label ambiguous (AMBI). Posts in MedSenti were taken directly from the forum. Therefore, there was a number that quoted previous posts, as is customary in such discussions. For example (italics cited): post id 130007 Authorized Member 17 September 2008 - 21: 01 PM "Authorized 2, on September 13, 2008, 10: 47 AM, said: Thank you all.Authorized 1 - which three clinics did you visit before compiling? Authorized hello? 2 I went to a center outside 3Fleiss kappa = 0.73 (Bobicev and Sokolova, 2015).Canada, then Lifequest and Create was the third that I waived. Hope this is helpfully authorized text" additional post "could be included in both of the citation in both of the document, as well as in both of the Qantini.

sections.heading: 4 Experiments
sections.text: In order to support our previously stated positions on understanding affective expressions in support forums, we conducted a series of experiments. As I said, our aim is not to achieve current results, but to highlight some of the challenges with current approaches.

sections.heading: 4.1 Broad methodology
sections.text: In this paper, we use a robust syntactic dependency synthesis parser (Ait-Mokhtar et al., 2001) to extract a wide range of textual features, from word phrases to more complex linguistic attributes. Our experiments are outlined as multi-class classification tasks using liblinar (Fan et al., 2008) and use 5x layered cross validation. It is worth noting that we are not using a cross-domain lexicon here. We have reimplemented the Health Affect Lexicon (Sokolova et al., 2013) and it has worked just as well as previously reported. However, few studies of such approaches have shown that such lexicon generalization and brand-based tuning is very task specific.

sections.heading: 4.2 Document Level analysis
sections.text: In this series of experiments, we consider each entry as a single unit of text with a single label.

sections.heading: 4.2.1 5-class classification
sections.text: We used a variety of combinations of different linguistic characteristics, ranging from simple word-based n-grams to semantic dependencies. To illustrate, we list the most powerful combinations: word unigrams, bigrams, and trigrams; binary markers for questions, conjunctions, and uppercase letters; and a broad polarity dictionary. Results can be found in Table 2Our best overall score (macro-averaged F1 = 0.449) is well above the baseline of the majority class (F = 0.110), which compares favorably with the six-class performance of semantic characteristics of the original data analysis (F1 = 0.397, Sokolova, and Bobicev, 2013). However, more important - and not previously reported - is the performance in the individual category, which gives more insight into the data. Essentially, we see ENCO, GRAT, and FACT perform relatively well, while CONF, and ENO in particular, are clearly classified as having a bad classification.

sections.heading: 4.2.2 One-vs-all
sections.text: To examine the error pattern in Table 3 more closely, we have tried to classify each category individually in a one-on-one task, and the results of this task, with a feature set consisting of word unigrams, bigrams, and trigrams, are presented in Table 4. Note that we report only for the target class, as the other class is complementary. Again, we see a similar performance pattern: ENCO and FACT differ most from the other classes, while CONF and ENDO are markedly less strong. It is worth noting that ENDO is particularly different from the rest of the corpus - although it is the third largest category, the F score is only 0.011. It is clear that this challenge is not trivial - there are distinct error patterns in the classification at the document level. To examine this further, we will move to the classification at the record level.

sections.heading: 4.3 Sentence Level analysis
sections.text: The 1137 entries from the MedSenti become 8071 sentences, MedSentisent. Manual annotations at the sentence level are not possible, as this would be a considerably expensive exercise. To mark the corpus with the five categories of feelings, we have examined the use of automated methods.

sections.heading: 4.3.1 Naı̈ve Labelling
sections.text: The most trivial approach to naming sentences is that each sentence inherits the label of the place in which it exists. By this naïve method, we obtain the distribution as in Table 5. We perform the 5-class classification scenario on MedSenti, using the same conditions and the previous best feature; the results will be in Table 6. Overall, the performance is worse than the post-level equivalent, with the exception of a small improvement over ENDO. FACT is the most powerful single category, though now with greater memory than precision. As at the document level, we examine the performance of the model more thoroughly with the error matrix in Table 7. The most important observation we make here is that the decline in the performance of the four subjective categories is largely due to an incorrect classification of sentences as FACT. Sentries in this category are the majority in MedSenti-Senti-Senti (more than twice as high as the closest category). However, the proportional differences do not seem to explain the significant changes in MedSenti.

sections.heading: 4.3.2 Subjectivity-informed labelling
sections.text: One approach to data relabeling is to take advantage of the rougher levels of annotation: that of subjectivity. Is it at least possible to distinguish which propositions are objective and could be called FACT? We developed a subjectivity model4 that was developed for the SemEval 2016 Aspect Based Sentiment Analysis Track (Pontiki et al., 2016), which was one of the most powerful models for polarity detection. In order to eliminate confusion with the FACT category, we eliminated objective propositions from propositions previously labeled with the 4 subjective categories. Since this "confusion" can be bidirectional, we also removed all subjective propositions that were previously FACT. To eliminate confusion with the FACT category, we eliminated objective propositions from propositions previously labeled with the 4 subjective categories.

sections.heading: 5 Discussion
sections.text: In fact, it is as if most people are able to survive themselves by surviving themselves. (...) It is not as if they survive themselves. (...) It is as if they survive themselves. (...) It is as if they survive themselves. (...) It is as if they survive themselves. (...) It is as if they survive themselves. (...) It is as if they survive themselves. (...) It is as if they survive themselves. (...) It is as if they survive themselves. (...) It is as if they survive themselves. (...) It is as if they survive themselves. (...) It is as if they survive themselves. (...) It is as if they survive themselves. It is as if they survive themselves, as if they survive, as if they survive. "(It is)" (It is) as if they survive. "

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: In this work, we have taken two positions: despite seemingly weak results at the sentence level, we are convinced that the examples we have provided show that document-level analysis is not enough to accurately capture emotional expressions in emotional support forums. We have also shown that there are important social dimensions in this type of area that should also be taken into account. It is clear that an automated understanding of this growing pool of data is of considerable benefit; we in the social NLP community need to consider some refined approaches to maximize both the value itself and its fidelity.

referenceMentions.context: In fact, further to merely enabling this affective expressionism, studies have shown that anonymity in online presence increases the chance of sharing more personal information and emotions when compared to face-to-face interactions (Hancock et al., 2007).
such as treatments or hospitals, and provide emotional support to others with similar experiences (Bringay et al., 2014).
This sharing through open discussion is known to be considerably beneficial (Pennebaker et al., 2001).
Sentiment mining on platforms such as Twitter, for example, can be seen as a quick method to gauge public opinion of government policies (Speriosu et al., 2011).
Much sentiment analysis research has focused on classifying the overall sentiment of a document or short text onto a positive-negative spectrum (Hu and Liu, 2004; Kim and Hovy, 2006).
Much sentiment analysis research has focused on classifying the overall sentiment of a document or short text onto a positive-negative spectrum (Hu and Liu, 2004; Kim and Hovy, 2006).

Recently, research work targeting finer grained analysis has emerged, such as aspect-based sentiment analysis (Liu, 2012; Pontiki et al., 2014), or semantic role labelling of emotions (Mohammad et al.

Even more than this, such affective expression often serve a social purpose (Rothman and Magee, 2016).
One work squarely in the public policy domain sought to classify tweets related to the recent health care reform in the US into positive and negative (Speriosu et al., 2011).

Ofek et al. (2013) use a dynamic sentiment lexicon to improve sentiment analysis in an online community for cancer survivors.

In selecting their data, Sokolova and Bobicev (2013) – as Ali et al. (2013) and others have done – tapped into the domain of on-line support communities.

In selecting their data, Sokolova and Bobicev (2013) – as Ali et al. (2013) and others have done – tapped into the domain of on-line support communities. Eastin and LaRose (2005) showed that people who seek support on-line – be it emotional or informational support – typically find it.

In selecting their data, Sokolova and Bobicev (2013) – as Ali et al. (2013) and others have done – tapped into the domain of on-line support communities. Eastin and LaRose (2005) showed that people who seek support on-line – be it emotional or informational support – typically find it. There are considerable benefits to participating in such groups. In a meta-analysis of 28 studies of healthbased forums, Rains and Young (2009) reported that participants perceive an increase in social support, a significant decrease in depression, and significant increases in both quality of life and selfefficacy in managing their condition.
Pfeil and Zaphiris (2007) identify four components of such communication: understanding, emotions, similarities and concerns.
In addition to direct support, another common dimension of such online groups is selfdisclosure (Prost, 2012).

Self-disclosure serves three social functions (Tichon and Shapiro, 2003): requesting implicit support by showing confusion and worries; providing support by sharing details of a personal experience and sharing information to further develop social relationships.
Barak and Gluck-Ofri (2007) identify self-disclosure as specific to open support groups (e.

The data used here1 is that of Bobicev and Sokolova (2015) – which is an extension to the data used, and described in more depth, in Sokolova and Bobicev (2013). Data was collected from discussion threads on a sub-forum of an In Vitro Fertilization (IVF) medical forum2 intended for discussion by participants who belong to a specific age-group (over 35s).

In labelling MedSenti Sokolova and Bobicev (2013) opted for the readercentric model and hence asked the annotators to analyse a post’s sentiment as if they were other discussion participants. This is an important differentiation for automated classification style tasks - models are built to predict how people will understand the emotion expressed, as opposed to the emotion or sentiment an author feels they are conveying. For example, Maks and Vossen (2013) showed in review texts that reader assigned scores were more reliably related to the language used than the original rating of the author.

The original authors report subsequently on incorporating context into their experiments: both in terms of the position within a discussion of a post (Bobicev and Sokolova, 2015) and the posting history of an author (Sokolova and Bobicev, 2015).

metadata.abstractText: Understanding expressions of emotions in support forums has considerable value and NLP methods are key to automating this. Many approaches understandably use subjective categories which are more finegrained than a straightforward polaritybased spectrum. However, the definition of such categories is non-trivial and, in fact, we argue for a need to incorporate communicative elements even beyond subjectivity. To support our position, we report experiments on a sentiment-labelled corpus of posts taken from a medical support forum. We argue that not only is a more fine-grained approach to text analysis important, but simultaneously recognising the social function behind affective expressions enable a more accurate and valuable level of understanding.
